name: NPR
text:
The sons of slain Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi say they have forgiven their father's killers, paving the way for a legal reprieve for 5 men sentenced to death for the murder.
https://t.co/4WvHX37p2C

name: NPR
text:
Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel said President Trump was gambling with public health through his pandemic response — including his refusals to wear a mask in public and defense of stay-at-home protesters. 
https://t.co/qDQ4yRyh9p

name: NPR
text:
Political analysts say China's growing assertiveness and its recent coronavirus disinformation campaign have soured relations and encouraged the British government to reconsider its China policy. 
https://t.co/9nR3fbTUI5

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden says he "shouldn't have been so cavalier" when he told a radio host that black voters “ain’t black” if they support President Trump.
https://t.co/KDGC7Ps6Dp

name: NPR
text:
A restaurant in Ocean City, Md., is using "bumper tables" to keep diners safely 6-feet apart. 

"It's like a big baby walker," the owner said. https://t.co/XFeFwesSMg

name: NPR
text:
Coronavirus cases among grocery store workers have increased by 200%, according to a union report.

The uptick in cases comes at a time some companies have ended the extra 'hero pay' for workers. https://t.co/KrAgkWzk1K

text:

https://t.co/cOdwBNK9G3

text:
An attack by a shooter at the Naval Air Station in Corpus Christi on Thursday was terrorism-related, the FBI said. Officials have identified the suspect as a 20-year-old Corpus Christi man. (@TPRNews)
https://t.co/G1LFibE0wL

name: NPR
text:
The Justice Department is backing a lawsuit challenging Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker's stay-at-home order, saying it significantly impairs the ability of residents "to maintain their economic livelihoods."
https://t.co/8b58kullG0

text:
Moby was once an unlikely pop star. Now he has become an unlikely and particularly ardent philanthropist — applying his zealotry to social causes, even when he has new music to promote.  
https://t.co/SiJRv5jId4

text: After journeying through England, Italy and Spain, comic duo Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon take one final trip, playing fictionalized versions of themselves as they retrace Odysseus' famed voyage. https://t.co/lWGy6aEIoP
